byline.contributor: Kirk Semple and Azam Ahmed reported from Mexico City, and Eric Lipton from Washington. Ana Graciela Méndez contributed reporting from Panama City, Simon Romero from Rio de Janeiro, and Alison Smale from Berlin.
byline.original: By KIRK SEMPLE, AZAM AHMED and ERIC LIPTON

abstract: Leak of confidential documents has laid bare operations at secretive Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca, which has made name for itself by offering absolute privacy to its clients, while also casting spotlight on country's financial and legal sectors; co-founder Ramon Fonseca says in interview that his firm has not committed any wrongdoing and avers that after investigation it will become clear only crime committed was hacking that led to leak.
lead_paragraph: Ramón Fonseca, a co-founder of Mossack Fonseca, proclaimed his firm’s innocence. But some say the leak’s contents are at odds with how he has tried to portray himself and his role in Panama.

headline.main: Panama Papers Leak Casts Light on a Law Firm Founded on Secrecy
